flags.excerpt: nothing has changed for revenue goals
flags.reasoning: Bessent's claim that tariff revenue will be 'virtually unchanged' relies on replacing IEEPA tariffs with Section 122 authority, which is capped at 15% and expires after 150 days unless Congress votes to extend it. The article does not convey these critical statutory limitations, creating a materially false impression that revenues are secure on the same terms. In reality, Section 122 is a time-limited and rate-capped fallback that represents a significant structural downgrade from IEEPA authority.

flags.excerpt: Supreme Court reaffirmed that the president has… the draconian alternative
flags.reasoning: The article frames the embargo power as a newly 'reaffirmed' and enhanced presidential tool. However, the court's ruling did not affirmatively expand or reaffirm presidential embargo power — it struck down IEEPA tariff authority. The majority opinion did not address embargo powers at all; Bessent's interpretation extrapolates from what the court did NOT prohibit rather than what it endorsed. Presenting this as a Supreme Court 'reaffirmation' of embargo authority mischaracterizes the ruling's scope.

flags.excerpt: Within three days, the President can put on the Section 122 10% global tariff
flags.reasoning: The article quotes Bessent's claim without noting key limitations: Section 122 tariffs are capped at 15% and automatically expire after 150 days unless Congress votes to extend them. The article also omits that Section 122 has never before been invoked to impose tariffs. These are material facts that significantly affect the credibility of Bessent's assertion that revenue will be 'virtually unchanged.'
